elements.content: The fine design and regulation of catalysts play critical roles in the development of catalysis. The microenvironment, which gives rise to unique spatial structures and electronic properties around catalytic sites, has been proven to dramatically regulate catalytic behavior in enzymes and homogeneous catalysis. However, understanding the microenvironment modulation (MEM) of catalytic sites remains challenging and very limited in heterogeneous catalysis mainly due to the lack of structural precision and/or tailorability of traditional solid catalysts. Among diverse materials, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), a class of porous crystalline solids, have been intensively studied as heterogeneous catalysts in recent years. The atomically precise and well tunable structures of MOFs make them an ideal platform for rationally regulating the microenvironment surrounding catalytic sites. Accordingly, their well-defined structures hold great promise for elucidating how the microenvironment modulation affects the resulting catalytic performance. Nevertheless, the investigations of accurate control over the microenvironment of catalytic sites in MOFs for modulated catalysis are still very limited. Therefore, it is of great importance to summarize the related results and provide in-depth insights into microenvironment modulation in MOF-based catalysis, accelerating the future development of this emerging research topic.

elements.content: In this Account, we have presented a summary of our recent attempts to optimize the catalytic performance of MOF-based materials via microenvironment modulation. In view of the unique component and structural advantages of MOFs, we deliver the general fundamentals for rational control over the microenvironment in MOF-based catalysis. Initially, the great opportunities brought about by MOFs for accurate control over microenvironment engineering, including the origin of abundant active sites, flexible regulation strategies, and well-defined structure, are introduced in detail. In the next section, we focus on the specific strategies of microenvironment modulation in MOF-based catalysis, which dominate the molecular/electron-transfer process and regulate the intrinsic activity of catalytic sites. Meanwhile, the related chemical basis and underlying structure–property relationship behind the enhanced catalytic performance will be highlighted. Finally, the major challenges and future outlooks on the microenvironment modulation in MOF-based catalysis will be further discussed. It is expected that this Account would provide an understanding of the importance of microenvironment modulation around catalytic sites in MOF-based catalysts and afford significant inspiration toward enhanced performance by microenvironment engineering in heterogeneous catalysis.

elements.content: Mimicking enzyme catalysis by the design of artificial analogs is very promising and has attracted a great amount of interest. The precise arrangement of amino acid residues in the catalytic pockets of enzymes induces the preferred orientation and preactivation of substrates via secondary coordination interactions, thereby giving rise to high activity and excellent selectivity. Inspired by enzyme catalysis, the microenvironment, which refers to the specific physicochemical environment surrounding catalytic sites and might interact with substrates and catalytic sites, is recognized to be as important as catalytic sites. Accordingly, the construction of an enzyme pocket-like reaction microenvironment has been pursued in heterogeneous catalysis. To achieve microenvironment modulation (MEM), although some artificial material platforms have been developed, unfortunately their vague structure and/or low tailorability are unfavorable. On account of this, the precise fabrication of targeted pocket and pore structure, featuring the molecularly customized microenvironment around catalytic sites, in structurally extended solids remains highly desired yet a great challenge.

Introduction

Mimicking enzyme catalysis by the design of artificial analogs is very promising and has attracted a great amount of interest. The precise arrangement of amino acid residues in the catalytic pockets of enzymes induces the preferred orientation and preactivation of substrates via secondary coordination interactions, thereby giving rise to high activity and excellent selectivity. Inspired by enzyme catalysis, the microenvironment, which refers to the specific physicochemical environment surrounding catalytic sites and might interact with substrates and catalytic sites, is recognized to be as important as catalytic sites. On account of this, the precise fabrication of targeted pocket and pore structure, featuring the molecularly customized microenvironment around catalytic sites, in structurally extended solids remains highly desired yet a great challenge.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), featuring an ultrahigh surface area, tunable pore size, and well-defined and tailorable structures, have been widely applied in various applications such as gas storage and separation, chemical sensors, catalysis, proton conductivity, and others. Among them, catalysis, one of the most promising applications of MOFs, has captured broad research interest and achieved significant progress. However, previous studies are mainly focused on the creation of catalytic sites and the investigation of catalytic performance by tailoring the structure and composition of MOFs. In fact, the microenvironment effect on the performance of heterogeneous catalysts and the underlying structure–performance relationship are fundamental issues at research frontiers in materials science and heterogeneous catalysis and remain largely elusive. On account of the infinite structural and component diversity of MOFs, it is expected that attractive biomimetic features would be brought about by microenvironment modulation in MOF-based catalytic system. Moreover, the atomically precise microenvironment and clear location of catalytic sites are able to provide clear pictures/evidence to unveil the structure–performance relationship in microenvironment-induced catalysis. Therefore, it is of significance to summarize this research field, though in its nascent stage, and provide deep insight into the critical roles of the microenvironment in MOF-based catalysis, thereby promoting its further development.

elements.content: Toward the future development of microenvironment modulation over heterogeneous catalysts, this Account will summarize our recent advances in microenvironment modulation achieved in MOF-based catalysis, placing an emphasis on the underlying mechanism behind the improved catalytic performance. This Account would start by presenting an overview of the great opportunities with which MOFs are endowed for accurate control over the microenvironment around catalytic sites. Next, we present the specific strategies for microenvironment modulation over MOF-based catalysts, mainly discussing the three key aspects: mass transport, electron transfer, and catalytic site modulation. In the meantime, the structure–property relationship behind the enhanced catalytic performance is carefully discussed. Finally, our brief outlook on current challenges and the future development of microenvironment engineering in MOF-based catalysis will be proposed.

elements.content: Inspired by enzymatic catalysis, the active sites in heterogeneous catalysts can be simply divided into two parts: the catalytic sites (the sites where substrate molecules bind and transform) and the microenvironment (functional units around catalytic sites assisting the catalytic process). In terms of the introduction of catalytic sites, the inorganic–organic hybrid feature of MOFs allows them to be readily functionalized by taking advantage of both organic and inorganic building units (). Specifically, the coordinatively unsaturated metal centers of MOFs can act as excellent Lewis acid sites directly to accept electrons of reactants and promote subsequent activation and conversion (a). Meanwhile, extrinsic organic/inorganic units can also be grafted onto metal nodes when there are available coordination vacancies, accordingly enriching the origin of catalytic sites. Moreover, the organic linker part is also easily functionalized by means of organic synthesis, endowing MOFs with abundant catalytic sites (b). In addition, given the permanent and high porosity, the encapsulation of diverse active guests into the pore space of MOFs can further extend the catalytic scenarios (c).

elements.content: In addition to the creation of catalytic sites, the well-defined and tailorable structure of MOFs makes them an ideal platform to engineer the microenvironment of catalytic sites at the atomic/molecular level, creating artificial pockets such as those in enzymes for enhanced catalytic performance (). To be specific, the porous structure enables high-percentage interfaces between catalytic sites (particularly guest components) and MOFs (supports) without disturbing the accessibility of the catalytic components, enabling MOF-based materials to be particularly well suited to regulate interactions between catalytic sites and the microenvironment created by MOFs. The pore/channel size and shape created by MOFs, as part of the microenvironment surrounding catalytic sites, can be finely tuned to control molecular transfer for size-selective catalysis (d). Moreover, both metal nodes and organic linkers can be modified at will to alter the local surrounding environments, working with the catalytic sites collaboratively to improve catalytic performance (e). The alteration of the morphology/particle size of MOFs or the spatial location of catalytic sites in MOFs can also bring about significant variations in the microenvironment (f,g). In addition to the flexible microenvironment modulation, the well-defined and tailorable structures of catalytic sites and MOFs in atomic precision provide great convenience to determine the mutual relationships among catalytic sites, the microenvironment, and reactants, facilitating insights into the intrinsic structure–function relationships. The highly porous and flexible reaction space, abundant origin of catalytic sites, and freely customizable microenvironment with structural precision at the atomic/molecular level enable MOFs to be a class of very promising heterogeneous catalysts to mimic the binding pockets of enzymes, achieving enzyme-like catalysis with the desired activity and selectivity.

Microenvironment Modulation over MOF-Based Materials for Enhanced Catalysis

MOF-based materials, with tailorable components and structures, are able to provide the unique microenvironment around catalytic sites, which is very different from the homogeneous catalysis in solution and probably provides variant reaction paths. Focusing on the key factors in catalytic process, different strategies have been developed to regulate mass and charge transfer as well as the intrinsic activity of catalytic sites, by means of microenvironment modulation, in MOF-based catalysis.

elements.content: In heterogeneous catalysis, mass transfer through the solid catalyst to catalytic sites is the basic premise in the catalytic process. Diffusion control over reactants to catalytic sites lays a foundation for regulating the catalytic activity and selectivity. To achieve good control over mass transfer in MOF-based catalysis, it is important to regulate the physical microenvironment by tuning the pore structure (size/shape) and/or chemical microenvironment such as the wettability. In this part, we will focus on the rational design of microenvironments in MOFs to realize size selectivity, fast diffusion, and the accumulation of reactants for enhanced activity and selectivity.
elements.clean_text:
Dominating Mass Transfer by Microenvironment Modulation

In heterogeneous catalysis, mass transfer through the solid catalyst to catalytic sites is the basic premise in the catalytic process. Diffusion control over reactants to catalytic sites lays a foundation for regulating the catalytic activity and selectivity. To achieve good control over mass transfer in MOF-based catalysis, it is important to regulate the physical microenvironment by tuning the pore structure (size/shape) and/or chemical microenvironment such as the wettability. In this part, we will focus on the rational design of microenvironments in MOFs to realize size selectivity, fast diffusion, and the accumulation of reactants for enhanced activity and selectivity.

elements.content: The introduction of catalytic sites in the confined space of MOFs can impose geometric restrictions on reactants by the MOF pore features, providing opportunities for regulating mass transfer. The uniform pore size distribution makes MOFs ideal “sieves” to allow the transport of substrates with specific molecular sizes while excluding substrate molecules that are larger than pore sizes. This geometric microenvironment, as a result, would impart the size-selective function when catalytic sites are confined in MOF-based catalysts.
elements.clean_text:
Size Selectivity/Sieving

The introduction of catalytic sites in the confined space of MOFs can impose geometric restrictions on reactants by the MOF pore features, providing opportunities for regulating mass transfer. The uniform pore size distribution makes MOFs ideal "sieves" to allow the transport of substrates with specific molecular sizes while excluding substrate molecules that are larger than pore sizes. This geometric microenvironment, as a result, would impart the size-selective function when catalytic sites are confined in MOF-based catalysts.

elements.content: To examine this capability of MOFs, we deliberately encapsulated Pd nanocubes (NCs) into ZIF-8 with small pore openings (3.4 Å), constructing the Pd NCs@ZIF-8 composite in a core–shell structure (a,b). The Pd NCs, being catalytic sites and well dispersed inside the ZIF-8 shell, present excellent stability and recyclability. In the catalytic hydrogenation reactions, the ZIF-8 shell serves as the “molecular sieve” to allow the permeation of reactants/products within specific sizes, thereby controlling the Pd catalytic selectivity. Benefitting from the molecular sieve effect of ZIF-8 together with the plasmonic photothermal effects of Pd NCs, Pd NCs@ZIF-8 presents high activity and size selectivity toward the hydrogenation of small olefins such as 1-hexene (molecular size ∼2.5 Å) at room temperature under 1 atm H2 and full-spectrum light irradiation. On the contrary, olefins larger than the pore size such as cyclooctene (∼5.5 Å) cannot reach the Pd sites and give no conversion (c).

elements.content: Not limited to metal NCs, molecular catalysts confined in MOFs are also able to show size-selective behavior, which otherwise cannot be achieved in the absence of MOF. Following this idea, we have successfully entrapped homogeneous molecular catalysts in the hollow MOF capsules for the catalytic cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides (d). Specifically, the presynthesized hollow layered double hydroxides (H-LDH), behaving as templates, direct the growth of MOFs on their surfaces to afford H-LDH@MOF composites, such as H-LDH@ZIF-8, with a defect-free MOF shell (e). The hollow space encompassed by interconnected MOF particles can be deemed a nanoreactor, mimicking a homogeneous environment for molecular catalysts to exert their intrinsic activity. Meanwhile, the continuous and compact MOF shell with a pore size smaller than the encapsulated molecular catalysts can prevent leaching of the latter. Accordingly, the accurate pore size of MOFs provides a steric microenvironment to afford size-selective catalysis of the inner molecular catalysts. When Co-porphyrin (Co-TCPP) was employed as a catalytic unit and confined in the cavity of H-LDH@ZIF-8, the as-formed Co-TCPP@H-LDH@ZIF-8 demonstrated the size-selective catalytic conversion of epoxides with small molecular size only, which cannot be achieved by the single Co-TCPP molecule (f). This clearly shows that MOFs with well-defined pore sizes can create particular geometric microenvironments and enable the size-selective catalysis of different substrates.

Molecular Diffusion

Though MOFs with specific pore sizes possess great superiority in size-selective catalysis, in some catalytic processes, the microporous characteristic of most MOFs severely slows or restricts the diffusion rates of reactants, particularly the bulky molecules. To meet this challenge, many strategies, such as enlarging the pore size of MOFs (minimizing diffusion resistance) and the construction of 2D MOFs (shortening the diffusion distance), have drawn great attention to accelerate mass transfer.

elements.content: Hierarchically porous MOFs (HP-MOFs), with a large content of mesopores/macropores, are regarded as promising candidates, offering an ideal microenvironment around catalytic sites for fast reactant/product feeding and release. With this in mind, a versatile modulator-induced defect-formation strategy has been developed. By introducing monocarboxylic acid as the modulator during MOF synthesis, a series of HP-MOFs including HP-UiO-66, HP-UiO-67, HP-MIL-53, HP-DUT-5, and HP-MOF-808, with tailorable pore sizes dependent on the length and concentration of monocarboxylic acid modulators, have been constructed successfully (a). Compared with the pristine microporous MOFs, the resultant HP-MOFs, with abundant mesoporous structures, would greatly accelerate the molecular diffusion of large substrate/product molecules during the reactions. Taking UiO-66 and HP-UiO-66 as examples, both of them are used in catalyzing the [3 + 3] cycloaddition reactions of α,β-unsaturated aldehydes with different sizes and 1,3-cyclohexanedione. For small aldehyde substrates such as 3-methyl-2-butenal, the activity of UiO-66 is a little lower than that of HP-UiO-66 (b). Remarkably, when a larger substrate such as cinnamaldehyde is introduced, HP-UiO-66 with hierarchical pores presents more pronounced superiority and shows significantly enhanced activity compared to that of pristine microporous UiO-66 (b).

elements.content: Reducing the MOF dimensionality, such as during the construction of 2D MOFs, which can shorten the diffusion distance of reactants to catalytic sites, is another effective way to accelerate the diffusion process. To this end, a novel intercalation and chemical exfoliation method has been developed to obtain MOF nanosheets with high yield (∼57%) from bulk MOF crystals (c). By intercalating 4,4′-dipyridyl disulfide (DPDS) into the layered porphyrinic MOF (Zn2(PdTCPP)) crystals to expand the interlayer distance of MOF followed by selective cleavage of the disulfide bonds in DPDS, bulk porphyrinic MOF can be easily exfoliated into 2D nanosheets (∼1 nm) (d,e). Taking advantage of the singlet oxygen (1O2) generation ability of metalloporphyrin under visible-light irradiation (λ > 420 nm), the oxidation of di­hydroxy­naphthalene (DHN) by 1O2 was adopted to compare the catalytic activity of Zn2(PdTCPP) crystals and nanosheets. The chemically exfoliated Zn2(PdTCPP) nanosheets, with a much shorter diffusion distance of reactants to the metalloporphyrin linkers, exhibit a much higher efficiency for 1O2 generation and DHN/1O2 diffusion than the bulk MOF. As a result, the 2D Zn2(PdTCPP) nanosheets present a much higher activity than bulk MOF in the photooxidation of DHN to juglone, clearly manifesting the superiority of the unique microenvironment created by 2D MOF nanosheets (f).

elements.content: Along this line, we have developed a facile poly­(di­methyl­siloxane) (PDMS) coating strategy to convert surface hydrophilic Pd/UiO-66 to hydrophobic Pd/UiO-66@PDMS without disturbing the Pd accessibility (a). elements.content: Not limited to the surface hydrophobic modification by PDMS, which is extendable to diverse solid materials, MOFs are highly modifiable to be hydrophobic throughout the structure. By means of a postmodification strategy, a series of perfluoroalkyl acids with different chain lengths, including trifluoroacetic acid (F3), penta­fluoro­propionic acid (F5), and heptafluorobutyric acid (F7), are grafted to the Zr-oxo nodes of metalloporphyrinic MOF, PCN-222­(Fe) (a). With an increased chain length of perfluorinated alkyls, PCN-222­(Fe)-F n has a higher water contact angle and prefers to enrich cyclohexane when being dispersed in a water–cyclohexane mixture (b). This illustrates the enhanced hydrophobicity of F-modified PCN-222­(Fe)-F n , and the higher F content corresponds to a more hydrophobic microenvironment, which would benefit the accumulation of hydrophobic substrates (b). Understandably, all PCN-222­(Fe)-F n samples show a higher conversion for the oxidation of hydrophobic cyclohexane than PCN-222­(Fe), based on Fe­(III) in the porphyrin center as a catalytic site (c). Furthermore, the best-performing PCN-222­(Fe)-F7 presents 90% selectivity and excellent stability to KA oil (composed of cyclohexanone and cyclohexanol), even higher than the requirement in industry (more than 80%) (d). The related results clearly prove that the hydrophobic microenvironment of MOFs greatly facilitates the enrichment and selective conversion of hydrophobic substrates.

Reducing the Charge Migration Distance

Minimizing the distance between the charge generation place and catalytic/reaction sites would effectively inhibit charge recombination and thus greatly improve the catalytic efficiency. elements.content: The porous characteristic of MOFs readies them for molecular diffusion into inner space, which provides the prerequisite to randomly regulate the spatial distribution of catalytic sites without affecting their accessibility, whether inside or outside the catalyst. By introducing uniform Pt NPs (∼3 nm) into the precursors of UiO-66-NH2 or assembling Pt NPs with presynthesized UiO-66-NH2, the Pt NPs can be deliberately encapsulated inside or supported on UiO-66-NH2, affording Pt@UiO-66-NH2 and Pt/UiO-66-NH2, respectively (a–c). Both components and structural parameters in both composites are fixed to be similar, with the spatial distribution of Pt NPs relative to MOFs being the only difference. Obviously, the interface percentage between Pt and MOF in Pt@UiO-66-NH2 is much higher than that in Pt/UiO-66-NH2, giving rise to a significant change in the microenvironment around Pt. UiO-66-NH2, with semiconductor-like character, can serve as the photosensitizer, and Pt NPs are ideal electron acceptors leading to enhanced photocatalytic performance. When employed as photocatalysts for H2 production, Pt@UiO-66-NH2, with Pt confined in MOF particles, greatly shortens the electron-transfer distance from the MOF to Pt, in sharp contrast to Pt/UiO-66-NH2. Therefore, the utilization efficiency of photogenerated electrons is greatly improved. As a result, Pt@UiO-66-NH2 shows 5 times higher activity than Pt/UiO-66-NH2 for photocatalytic hydrogen generation (d). Ultrafast transient absorption (TA) spectroscopy indicates that Pt@UiO-66-NH2, with faster TA decay kinetics than Pt/UiO-66-NH2, can better promote the charge-separation process. Time-resolved photoluminescence (PL) decay profiles show that Pt@UiO-66-NH2 can more efficiently inhibit charge carrier recombination than Pt/UiO-66-NH2 (e). Time-resolved PL decay profiles, together with TA spectra, clearly reveal that the variation of Pt locations results in a much higher charge-transfer efficiency from the MOF to Pt in Pt@UiO-66-NH2 than in Pt/UiO-66-NH2. This work clearly suggests that the location of active guests (particularly metal NPs) relative to MOF, which dominates the interface percentage between MOF and the active guests, can significantly affect the microenvironment around the active guests (e.g., catalytic sites), leading to distinctly different catalytic activities.

elements.content: In another example, Au nanorods, capable of harvesting visible light, are introduced to further underscore the critical role of Pt relative to MOFs in catalysis. The Pt NPs (∼3 nm) are incorporated into or supported on a Ti-based MOF, MIL-125, affording Pt@MIL-125 and Pt/MIL-125 composites, respectively. Femtosecond time-resolved transient absorption (fs-TA) spectra reveal that the average relaxation lifetimes are 615 ± 22, 553 ± 21, 376 ± 5, 881 ± 53, and 1167 ± 101 ps for UiO-66-NH2-X (X = 0, 50, 100, 150, 200), respectively. This work provides significant inspiration for microenvironment modulation (around the guest cocatalyst) by defect engineering of MOFs to promote photocatalysis.

Enhancing the Intrinsic Activity of Catalytic Sites by Microenvironment Modulation

The regulation of the intrinsic activity of catalytic sites by the microenvironment, although widely observed in homogeneous catalysis, has been rarely achieved in heterogeneous catalysis. MOFs, featuring atomic-level structural precision and tailorability, are able to realize accurate modulation over the electronic states and the coordination environment of catalytic sites, thereby enhancing their intrinsic activity.

elements.content: Although many catalytic studies have been reported on metal-NP-incorporated MOF composites, most of which focus on the introduction and utilization of metal NPs, the influence of the chemical microenvironment on the electronic state of catalytic sites has been seldom investigated and remains largely elusive. With this in mind, a series of isoreticular UiO-66-X (X = H, OMe, NH2, 2OH, 2OH­(Hf)) with various functional groups and metal ions have been constructed and served as hosts to encapsulate active Pd NPs in the pores, affording Pd@UiO-66-X composites (a). By altering the functional groups and metal ions (in the Zr/Hf-oxo cluster) of UiO-66-X, the chemical microenvironment of Pd can be easily regulated to modulate the electronic interaction between Pd and the MOF hosts. The diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform (DRIFT) spectra manifest apparent red shifts of CO adsorption on Pd@UiO-66-X due to electron transfer from the functional groups of the MOFs to Pd (b). Meanwhile, the degree of electron donation to Pd follows the order Pd@UiO-66-2OH > Pd@UiO-66-2OH­(Hf) > Pd@UiO-66-NH2 > Pd@UiO-66-OMe > Pd@UiO-66. Moreover, the substrate adsorption energy of Pd@UiO-66-X can also be influenced, following the order −OH < −2OH­(Hf) < −NH2 < −OMe < −H based on the theoretical calculation. Because of the different electronic states of Pd and the accompaning adsorption energy variation achieved by microenvironment modulation, Pd@UiO-66-X composites present distinctly different activity in the hydrogenation of benzoic acid (c). Pd@UiO-66-OH, featuring a high electronic state of Pd and moderate benzoic acid adsorption energy, displays the highest activity (c).

elements.content: The photogenerated electron transfer between MOFs and other active components can be employed as another promising way to modulate the electronic state of catalytic sites. In this case, the MOFs under light excitation, with variable photogenerated electrons by altering the light intensity, might provide different microenvironments for encapsulated catalytic sites. To demonstrate this, photosensitive Pt nanocrystals with a localized surface plasmon resonance (LSPR) effect and porphyrinic MOF, PCN-224­(Zn), with a visible-light adsorption ability, are deliberately integrated, forming Pt/PCN-224­(Zn) composites (d,e). Under light irradiation, two electron-transfer processes might take place in the opposite direction between the MOF and Pt due to the Schottky junction (electrons from the MOF to Pt) and plasmonic effect of Pt (electrons from Pt to the MOF) (d). By varying the light intensity, the competition between the Schottky junction and the plasmonic effect can be modulated. This makes it easy to dominate the electron-transfer direction between Pt and the MOF in Pt/PCN-224­(Zn), thereby regulating the electron state on the Pt surface. Taking advantage of the 1O2 production and photothermal effect caused by Pt and PCN-224­(Zn) under light irradiation, Pt/PCN-224­(Zn) exhibits excellent performance in the oxidation of aromatic alcohols. The electronic state of Pt, closely associated with 1O2 generation, can be adjusted flexibly by varying the light intensity (60–140 mW/cm2, λ > 400 nm). Under light irradiation at low intensity (<100 mW/cm2), PCN-224­(Zn) is readily photoexcited and injects electrons into Pt, making Pt more electron-rich, benefiting 1O2 generation and benzyl alcohol oxidation (f). Under a much higher light intensity (>100 mW/cm2), Pt will be excited due to the plasmonic effect and will reversely inject hot electrons into the MOF, in a more competitive way than for the Schottky junction, leading to the reduced Pt electron density and inferior activity (f). This work provides an effective and very promising way to modulate the electronic microenvironments of catalytic sites by external-field-stimuli-induced charge transfer, opening a new door to the regulation of the intrinsic activity of catalytic sites.

elements.content: For catalytic sites stabilized by coordination interaction, the basic microenvironment, namely, the coordination environment, lays the foundation for modulating the electronic state of catalytic sites. MOF-based single-atom catalysts (SACs), with singly dispersed metal atoms stabilized via a coordination interaction with the support, are ideal research objects. By the pyrolysis of bimetallic MgNi-MOF-74 incorporated with polypyrrole (PPy) inside the channels (PPy@MgNi-MOF-74) at different temperatures, a series of single-atom Ni catalysts with different N coordination numbers, named NiSA-N x -C (x = 2, 3, 4), have been obtained (a). The variation of the coordination number indicates that the single Ni atom possesses a different coordination microenvironment in these samples. NiSA-N2-C, featuring the lowest N coordination number, achieves much higher CO selectivity than NiSA-N3-C and NiSA-N4-C in the CO2 electroreduction, which clearly underscores the significant role of the coordination microenvironment in catalysis (a). Density functional theory (DFT) calculations further elucidate that the reduced N coordination number of a single Ni atom in NiSA-N2-C favors the formation of the COOH* intermediate, which is the rate-determining step for CO2 reduction to CO, accordingly accelerating the catalytic process.

elements.content: Manipulating the electron spin state of catalytic metal atoms by microenvironment modulation is of great importance yet is rarely achieved and reported. Very recently, we successfully implemented the electron spin state manipulation in Co-based covalent-organic frameworks (COFs). By altering the cobalt salts of Co­(CH3COO)2·4H2O and CoCl2·6H2O, the porphyrin centers of COF-367 are metalated with CoII and CoIII ions, producing COF-367-CoII and COF-367-CoIII, respectively (b). Different from the generation of COF-367-CoII by Co­(CH3COO)2·4H2O, the use of CoCl2 can introduce Cl– for charge balance in the overall framework, and the existence of Cl– provides a negative charge microenvironment to guarantee the existence of CoIII in COF-367-CoIII. The XPS measurement presents clear experimental evidence of the exclusive existence of CoIII in COF-367-CoIII, proving the significant role of Cl– in the formation of CoIII. COF-367-CoIII with a low-spin state of Co (S = 0) presents much higher activity and selectivity for HCOOH than COF-367-CoII with a low-spin state of Co (S = 1/2) in the photocatalytic CO2 reduction (b). DFT calculations disclose that CoIII in COF-367-CoIII favors the formation of HCOOH and possesses a much higher energy barrier for HCOOH conversion than does COF-367-CoII. This work paves the way for catalytic performance regulation by manipulating the spin state of catalytic metal centers, which is triggered by the change in the charge microenvironment. Considering that the porphyrin units are commonly used in MOFs, we believe that this strategy is definitely extendable to MOF-based catalysis.

Simultaneously Improving Mass Transfer and the Electronic State by Microenvironment Modulation

Given that mass transfer, electron transfer, and the intrinsic activity of catalytic sites are all influenced by microenvironment modulation, they can be simultaneously improved in some cases on the basis of the elaborate design and synthesis of MOF-based materials, leading to greatly boosted catalytic performances.

elements.content: We selected MIL-101-NH2 as a host to encapsulate naked Pd NPs, affording the Pd@MIL-101-NH2 composite (a). Then, a series of hydrophobic perfluoroalkyls, formulated as C n F2n+1CO-R (n = 1, 2, 3 and R = −OOCC n F2n+1; n = 5, 7 and R = −OH), were grafted onto the MOF based on postsynthetic modification between −NH2 and −COR groups, yielding Pd@MIL-101-F x (x = 3, 5, 7, 11, 15) composites with a hydrophobic microenvironment around Pd; the longer perfluoroalkyl chains result in stronger hydrophobicity of the pore walls (b). Moreover, the perfluoroalkyl chains on the MOF skeleton induce the electron transfer from Pd to MIL-101-F x , as clearly evidenced by the positive shifts in Pd XPS peaks and the red shifts in CO-DRIFTS adsorption peaks after hydrophobic modification (c,d). As a result, optimal Pd@MIL-101-F3, capable of enriching hydrophobic substrates, has a much higher efficiency than Pd@MIL-101-NH2 in the hydrogenation of various (hydrophobic) halogenated nitrobenzenes. More strikingly, electron-deficient Pd results in the preferable adsorption of −NO2 over the −Cl and −Br groups, as the former is more negatively charged, resulting in the highly selective hydrogenation of the −NO2 group over the dehalogenation of halogenated nitrobenzenes (e), far surpassing the traditional Pd-based catalysts. This is a classical and important example illustrating the simultaneous regulation of mass transfer and the electronic state of catalytic sites by controlling their surrounding microenvironment, finally boosting both activity and selectivity in heterogeneous catalysis.

elements.content: In this Account, we have summarized our recent contributions to microenvironment-modulated catalysis in MOF-based systems. We have discussed in detail how the microenvironment around catalytic sites can be modulated to improve the performance in MOF-based catalysis: (1) By tuning the pore size and geometry as well as the surface wettability of MOFs, mass transfer can be finely modulated and molecular sieving, recognition, and accumulation can be achieved during catalysis. Accordingly, the intrinsic activity/selectivity of metal sites will be further improved. Conclusions and Outlook

In this Account, we have summarized our recent contributions to microenvironment-modulated catalysis in MOF-based systems. We have discussed in detail how the microenvironment around catalytic sites can be modulated to improve the performance in MOF-based catalysis: (1) By tuning the pore size and geometry as well as the surface wettability of MOFs, mass transfer can be finely modulated and molecular sieving, recognition, and accumulation can be achieved during catalysis. (2) Altering the spatial distribution of catalytic guests and the concentration of structural defects in MOFs is able to change the environment around catalytic sites, which effectively influences the charge-transfer kinetics in photocatalysis. (3) The electronic state and spin state of catalytic metal sites can also be regulated by microenvironment engineering. Accordingly, the intrinsic activity/selectivity of metal sites will be further improved. In addition, the synergetic enhancement of the above factors by rational microenvironment modulation, such as the simultaneously improving mass transfer and intrinsic activity of catalytic sites, has been successfully realized to afford satisfied activity and selectivity in MOF-based catalysis.

elements.content: In spite of the above-mentioned progress in this topic, microenvironment modulation in heterogeneous catalysis is in its infancy. This is almost the starting point for microenvironment-modulated catalysis over MOF-based materials, and many challenges are still to be overcome. (1) In this early stage, it is imperative to come up with more strategies for microenvironment modulation in MOF-based catalysts. More microenvironment factors, such as hydrogen bonding and electrostatic/van der Waals/coordination interactions, might be introduced to assist with enriching, organizing, and activating the substrate and/or intermediate stabilization, thereby boosting the activity/selectivity. Meanwhile, the pore space partition, a unique strategy which can tune pore geometric features and strengthen the stability of MOFs, might be also promising to modulate the microenvironment and influence the catalytic process. (2) In addition to accurate control over the single aspect of the microenvironment, the simultaneous regulation of the mass/electron transfer and intrinsic behavior of catalytic sites would be better in mimicking the complex enzymatic catalysis and would lead to better performance. (3) The detailed mechanisms with regard to the specific interaction between catalytic sites and the microenvironment in MOF-based materials are waiting for in-depth studies. Not only the aforementioned interaction but also the reaction transition states and the well-defined and tailorable MOF structures should be of great help in regulating and understanding. On the basis of this ideal platform, more advanced characterizations and operando techniques might be necessary to obtain insightful information.

In another example, Au nanorods, capable of harvesting visible light, are introduced to further underscore the critical role of Pt relative to MOFs in catalysis. The Pt NPs (∼3 nm) are incorporated into or supported on a Ti-based MOF, MIL-125, affording Pt@MIL-125 and Pt/MIL-125 composites, respectively. Upon further supporting Au nanorods, which can harvest long-wavelength light based on the localized surface plasmon resonance (LSPR) effect, on the external surface of both composites, Pt@MIL-125/Au and Pt/MIL-125/Au composites are obtained, respectively (a,b). Strikingly, the obtained Pt@MIL-125/Au significantly accelerates charge transfer from the MOF to Pt with much higher photocurrent response than Pt/MIL-125/Au, although they possess a similar light-harvesting ability (c). As a result, Pt@MIL-125/Au presents excellent photocatalytic activity for hydrogen production (1743.0 μmol g–1 h–1) under visible light irradiation, over 10 times higher than that of Pt/MIL-125/Au (d). This further highlights the significant role of catalytic guest location relative to MOFs in the resulting catalytic performance.

A series of UiO-66-NH2-X (X = 0, 50, 100, 150, 200, representing the molar equivalents of modulator with respect to the linker during synthesis) with different contents of structural defects, are constructed, creating a modulated microenvironment for the incorporated Pt NPs (a). The Pt@UiO-66-NH2-X catalysts, with similar Pt loading (∼1 wt %), present an evident volcano-type trend with the increase in defects in photocatalytic hydrogen production, and Pt@UiO-66-NH2-100 with the moderate defect level exhibits the highest catalytic activity for H2 production (b). Femtosecond time-resolved transient absorption (fs-TA) spectra reveal that the average relaxation lifetimes are 615 ± 22, 553 ± 21, 376 ± 5, 881 ± 53, and 1167 ± 101 ps for UiO-66-NH2-X (X = 0, 50, 100, 150, 200), respectively. The fastest relaxation of UiO-66-NH2-100 manifests its highest charge-separation efficiency, supporting the best activity of Pt@UiO-66-NH2-100 (b,c). This work provides significant inspiration for microenvironment modulation (around the guest cocatalyst) by defect engineering of MOFs to promote photocatalysis.
